The verdict

A two-thirds majority (67 votes) is required to

convict the president, setting up his removal

from office. Democrats would have to win over

many Republican votes for this to happen.

67 votes needed

If a majority

votes to convict,

then Trump is

removed from office.

If the vote fails,

then Trump stays

in office.

The process ends.

The verdict

A two-thirds majority (67 votes) is required to convict the president.

Democrats, and the independents who caucus with them, would

have to win over at least 17 Republican votes for this to happen.

67 votes needed

If the vote fails,

Trump is acquitted for

the second time.

If Trump is convicted,

the Senate then moves to a

simple-majority vote on whether

to bar him from future office.

The verdict

A two-thirds majority (67 votes) is required

to convict the president. Democrats, and

the independents who caucus with them,

would have to win over at least 17 Republican

votes for this to happen.

67 votes needed

If Trump is convicted,

the Senate then moves

to a simple-majority vote

on whether to bar him

from future office.

If the vote fails,

Trump is acquitted

for the second

time.
